events.name: The cabbage Salon: The Self...and Other Drgs ¬∑ Luma
events.description:
https://lu.ma/43m8iiy5

‚ÄãThe cabbage Salon is a space for curious minds, deep discussions, and unexpected connections. Each gathering brings people together to engage with big ideas‚Äîguided by a speaker, and shaped by the thoughts, experiences, and perspectives of everyone in the room.

‚ÄãNo academic background required‚Äîjust a willingness to think, share, and listen.

‚ÄãThis salon is inspired by the texts of Johann Gottlieb Fichte, Thomas Nagel, Max Horkheimer, Theodor W. Adorno, and Robert Nozick.*

‚ÄãThe Self‚Ä¶

‚ÄãWe take for granted that each of us has a self‚Äîan ‚ÄúI.‚Äù The ‚ÄúI‚Äù in ‚ÄúI see the tree‚Äù or ‚ÄúI like this band.‚Äù But if we take a closer look, the ‚ÄúI‚Äù, that we are, becomes strangely elusive: If we try to focus on our pure ‚ÄúI‚Äù‚Äîstripped of any thought beyond the self-aware ‚ÄúI‚Äù‚Äîit slips from our grasp. The closer we try to get to it, the further it moves away. Trippy! What can we learn from philosophy about the nature of the self?

‚Äã...and Other Drgs**

‚ÄãWhat are we seeking when we take mind-altering substances? The list of possible answers is long: self-improvement, self-destruction, self-purification... Do we seek liberation, community, chaos, or the unknown? None of the above? And what if there were a drg‚Äîinexpensive, free from side effects‚Äîthat simply made us happier? Should we take it? Why‚Äîor why not? 

‚ÄãPresented By:

‚ÄãGeorg Spoo, PhD. is an Assistant Professor of Philosophy, who practiced his Postdoc at Columbia University. His academic research focus is on epistemology, social and political philosophy, and existentialism. He currently consults with companies to incorporate philosophical ideas into the practical business world. Teams have benefitted from Georg‚Äôs discussions on the philosophy of decision-making so they‚Äôre equipped to make better ones. At the heart of Georg‚Äôs beliefs is that everyone should live in peace, and no one should have to suffer inequality.

‚ÄãHow We Do Things:

‚Äãüîπ Warm-Up: We start with a short icebreaker to get minds moving and ideas flowing.
üîπ Talk & Discussion: Our guest speaker introduces the theme, sharing insights and questions to consider.
üîπ Group Conversations: Attendees break into small groups to explore the topic, bringing their own ideas and experiences into the mix.
üîπ More Talk, More Conversation: Our speaker presents a second round of thoughts, deepening the discussion before another round of open dialogue.
üîπ Final Thoughts & Closing: We wrap up with reflections, takeaways, and an open floor for last thoughts.

‚ÄãThis is not a lecture‚Äîit‚Äôs a conversation. Bring your point of view, your questions, and your curiosity. Get weird, get controversial, get real, baby. 

‚ÄãCome for the ideas, stay for the drinks, lovers, and friends. üç∑

‚Äã*If you'd like to dig deeper on these texts, it is absolutely not required and you won't feel lost if you haven't. But we've put them together for you here, anyways.

‚Äã**idk what the rules of the Internet are these days please don't clown us for censoring

‚Äã***Seating is limited, so first come first serve. But standing is good for you, someone said somewhere once.

‚Äã****If cost is an issue, please reach out @cabbagehousekids, everyone is welcome!

events.name:
Modern
Kintsugi NY
events.description: The art of Kintsugi embodies new beauty made through imperfections. It‚Äôs an artistry of mending broken pieces, symbolically representing how brokenness in our lives can transform to places of beauty and power. Instead of hiding chipped and broken parts,when imperfections are pronounced with the gold, symbolizing the light, you behold something that‚Äôs more beautiful. It‚Äôs an art form of mending to make new. In this Gather, we‚Äôll have an open time to share personal discovery with each other as we apply Kintsugi to a piece we‚Äôve each brought with us. We‚Äôll share a time of personal reflection and beholding through working with our hands.

events.name:
Suminagashi
Paper Marbling
events.description: Making marbled paper using ink, water, breath, and paper can connect us to the nature of life, art, and creative practice. In this Gather experience, explore the nature of Suminagashi, the meditative paper marbling process. You‚Äôll learn the history of the process, learn how this marbling style connects to nature and play, be guided through the materials and steps, and meditate on the shape and form of ink as you make marbled paper design. Discover the mesmerizing, mindful creative practice of Suminagashi and relax into the flow.

events.name:
Tea
Formulation
events.description: There are many kinds of herbalism. But there‚Äôs greater healing potency when there‚Äôs thoughtfulness and care that goes into making unique blends for yourself and for others. This is caring for your health in a slower but more natural way. In this Gather, we‚Äôll experience the intimacy of herbs through herbal tea formulation. We‚Äôll explore the importance and beauty of knowing the whole constitution of a person, plant, and conditions. We‚Äôll smell each herb and come to understand the broad strokes of the world of herbs. We‚Äôll learn to thoughtfully compose custom blends for a uniquely designed human.

events.name: Ikebana
events.description: Flowers bring the beauty of the natural world inside. And Ikebana‚Äîthe traditional Japanese art of flower arranging‚Äîallows us to play with movement, texture, and shape in order to create botanical sculptures. In this Gather, we‚Äôll use farm fresh flowers, dried foliage, minimal ingredients, and simple mechanics to create two Ikebana designs. One design will be in a provided Ikebana vessel, and the other will be done in a vessel we‚Äôve each brought with us. We‚Äôll learn to attach flower frogs and explore different design approaches. We‚Äôll then celebrate each others‚Äô art pieces while enjoying light snacks and conversation.

events.name:
Playful
Mark Making
events.description: When a wash of ink spreads across the paper in an unanticipated way, we can become the creator of an exquisitely made mark. This kind of encounter can often happen when we approach a sketchbook with an attitude of play‚Äîwith a new tool or a new way of moving the hand across the surface of the paper. In this Gather, we‚Äôll explore how we make marks on a surface‚Äîlike stamping with ink, drawing with a comb, and painting on yupo paper. We will experiment with these tools to create our own unique and unexpected textures. This can open up a new vocabulary of textures to apply to our creative practices across any medium.

events.name: Derek Parfit's Birthday!
events.description:
Derek Parfit¬†was perhaps the greatest moral philosopher of the 20th century, in how he shaped the discipline and raised important new questions.¬†

He gave us the Repugnant Conclusion and the Hitchhiker's Dilemma, and put a plug for giving 10% into On What Matters, his masterpiece. Had he lived long enough to finish another volume, he had plans¬†to discuss existential risk and dive deeper into questions of how we ought to act.

How to celebrate Parfit's life and work? You could discuss population ethics, philosophize about something else, or consider, as a group, ways to make your lives slightly more rational. (Or just eat cake and sing Happy Birthday and engage in idle, friendly conversation; Parfit surely wouldn't object.)

events.name: Empire-Brooklyn Speed Training
events.description:
Group inline speedskating practice on the Prospect Park loop organized by the Empire and Brooklyn Speed Teams.

Practices are held Sunday mornings from the start of April until the end of September, but may begin in March and end in October if weather and temperatures permit.

Meet-up is at the Bartel-Pritchard Circle entrance to Prospect Park, at the intersection of Prospect Park West and 15th St.¬†Start time varies from 8:30 or 9 a.m. most of the summer but may be later in spring and autumn, depending on expected general use of the loop. So always check in with the¬†Empire Speed FB page¬†and/or with other skaters beforehand to find out exactly when it is.

The first loop is usually a warm up loop, and new-ish speedskaters should be able to hang on. After that the pace speeds up, and slower skaters may have to form a B group.

events.name: NYC Wednesday Night Skate
events.description:
NYC's largest group skate, rolling spring through autumn.

WNS starts meeting about 7:45 p.m. on the south side of Union Square, at the intersection of Broadway and 14th S., and rolls out at 8:00.

WNS skates about 12-15 miles (20-25 km). Most routes are circuits around Manhattan, perhaps looping around Midtown and Downtown or maybe heading up to Grant's Tomb and back. But WNS sometimes crosses the bridges to Queens and/or Brooklyn, such as during its popular Three Bridges skate.

WNS usually finishes about 10:15, ending at a skate friendly pub near Union Square.

WNS is an intermediate level group skate. Skaters must be accustomed to skating after dark and on city streets with traffic. The pace is typical of most group skates.

Safety:¬†Please wear helmet and wrist guards. Light-colored or reflective clothing is also recommended as are blinkies or other illumination.

More info and announcements available on the WNS Facebook page.

Leader: WNS Staff
Level: Intermediate to advanced.

venue.address: Union Square, New York, NY 10003, USA

events.name: Empire Speed CP Loop Training
events.description:
Group inline speedskating practice on the Central Park loop by the Empire Skate Club's speed team.

Meet-up is at Speedskaters Curb, located on the west side of the Central Park loop just north of Tavern on the Green (W 67th St.), at 7¬†p.m.

Empire Speed training in Central Park from mid spring to mid autumn usually occurs one or two weekday evenings per week. Please note that this Thursday session is weather permitting. There is no make-up date in case of rain.

Announcements and updates about Empire Speed sessions are posted on the¬†Empire Speed Facebook page, often with short¬†notice (rarely more than 24 hours, and often just maybe 9-10 hours).

events.description:
This is a tentative calendar entry. Event dates will not be confirmed until spring 2025.

New York City's annual group skate weekend, organized by the Empire Skate Club.

The skating begins Wednesday evening with a special edition of the Wednesday Night Skate. There will then be Empire-organized group skates Thursday evening, Friday morning and evening, Saturday morning/afternoon and¬†Sunday morning/afternoon.

The Friday evening skate should conclude with a party, and the turnaround for Saturday's long skate should be at a restaurant. There will also be raffles, clinics and more.

All Empire-organized group skates that are part of the Big Apple Roll will start from the event hotel.

Health and safety notice:¬†Please wear helmet and wrist guards. Light-colored or reflective clothing is also recommended during evening/night skates, as are blinkies or other illumination.¬†

Many more details about BAR can be found on the event website.

Leader: Empire staff

events.name: Pre-Marathon Speed Skate
events.description:
Informal (as in, not sponsored by any organization) group skate following the course of the NYC Marathon before the runners take over.¬†This is a fast paced skate for advanced skaters. Group will start rolling ASAP and will endeavor to follow as much of the course as possible before the Queensboro Bridge is blocked off and before the streets are closed off by the police. If skaters make good time, they can roll over the QBB traffic lanes without (OMG, the embarrassment) taking the subway across the East River.

Safety/health notice:¬†Helmet and other protective gear are strongly recommended.

Level: Advanced

events.name: Empire Sunday Marathon Watching Skate
events.description:
Group skate to watch runners in the NYC Marathon.

Group meets at Dante Park at Broadway and West 63rd St (across from Lincoln Center) at 9:30 a.m. and skates to East Harlem to see the lead runners heading up First Ave. and again as they head down Fifth Ave. Afterwards, the group will roll around upper Manhattan and the Bronx to watch and cheer on later runners. The group might also make a visit to the Bronx Brewery and/or Yankee Stadium and/or the High Bridge and/or a skate-friendly restaurant.

This group skate will include skating on city streets. Skaters must be accustomed to skating alongside city traffic.

Safety/health notice:¬†Helmet and protection gear are strongly recommended.

Leader: Westchester Pete
Level: Intermediate

events.name: Winter Village in Bryant Park
The Orchid Show
events.description: The Orchid Show: Mexican Modernism Promises a Breathtaking Display of Orchids in a Sensory Journey to Mexico City, from February 15 through  April 27, 2025.\nExperience the vibrant hues and captivating beauty of The Orchid Show: Mexican Modernism. Embark on a journey to Mexico City, where the fusion of tradition and modern artistry takes center stage amid breathtaking displays of orchids. Wander through lush landscapes adorned with thousands of orchids, showcasing Mexico’s diverse ecosystems and rich cultural history. Marvel at intricate arrangements of orchids in displays that evoke the color-saturated designs of Mexican modernist architect Luis Barragán transported to the nybg.org • T 718.817.8700 • F 718.220.6504 2900 Southern Boulevard, Bronx, NY 10458-5126Bronx. Whether you’re a seasoned orchid enthusiast or an NYBG newcomer, this exhibition promises a feast for the senses and a celebration of Mexico’s rich botanical history. On select Saturday evenings during The Orchid Show, adults 21 and over can experience Orchid Nights, a picture-perfect night out, with music and dancing, cash bars, and food available for purchase.  \n

events.description: The Orchid Show: Mexican Modernism Promises a Breathtaking Display of Orchids in a Sensory Journey to Mexico City, from February 15 through  April 27, 2025.\nExperience the vibrant hues and captivating beauty of The Orchid Show: Mexican Modernism. Embark on a journey to Mexico City, where the fusion of tradition and modern artistry takes center stage amid breathtaking displays of orchids. Wander through lush landscapes adorned with thousands of orchids, showcasing Mexico’s diverse ecosystems and rich cultural history. Marvel at intricate arrangements of orchids in displays that evoke the color-saturated designs of Mexican modernist architect Luis Barragán transported to the nybg.org • T 718.817.8700 • F 718.220.6504 2900 Southern Boulevard, Bronx, NY 10458-5126Bronx. Whether you’re a seasoned orchid enthusiast or an NYBG newcomer, this exhibition promises a feast for the senses and a celebration of Mexico’s rich botanical history. On select Saturday evenings during The Orchid Show, adults 21 and over can experience Orchid Nights, a picture-perfect night out, with music and dancing, cash bars, and food available for purchase.  \n

events.name: Easter Parade and Easter Bonnet Festival
events.description: Each year on Easter, celebrants don festive finery and show off their very best bonnets along Fifth Avenue. Immortalized by Irving Berlin (with some help from Judy Garland and Fred Astaire), the pageant is a New York City tradition that stretches back to the 1870s.Starting at about 10am and continuing until 4pm, the parade marches north on Fifth Avenue, from 49th Street to 57th Street. The best place to watch is from the area around St. Patrick's Cathedral; better yet, bring your bonnet and join the parade.

venue.name: The parade marches north on Fifth Avenue, from 49th Street to 57th Street.
venue.address: The parade marches north on Fifth Avenue, from 49th Street to 57th Street.

events.name: Robot Karaoke
events.description:
Join us for karaoke night on impossible mode as we replace the lyrics to any SONG with words from any TEXT, then try to sing the results on the spot.  It all happens live, so each song has never been heard before and will never be heard again.
Our songwriting system, THE WEIRD ALGORITHM, matches each line syllable-for-syllable, so you can sing along if you know the original tune.
Request any of the 100+ songs and 50+ texts in the catalog. Sign up to sing as an individual or a group...or sit back and watch the karaoke carnage.
Past combos include:
YELP REVIEWS OF PSYCHICS to the tune of TOTAL ECLIPSE OF THE HEART
CRAIGSLIST VEHICLE ADS to the tune of TAKE ME HOME COUNTRY ROADS

events.name: AnimeNEXT 2009: The Found Footage Documentary - 1st Public Screening!
events.description:
The anime con experience of yesteryear packed into a hot wild 80 minutes.
AnimeNEXT 2009: The Found Footage documentary aims to simply evoke the magic of the anime convention golden years via a preserved three day convention experience, nothing more nothing less.
Comprised entirely of old digi-cam footage from an era before everything was manicured for social media & the cell phone camera, the documentary throws you right into the con, forcing all to bask in awe of these bygone, earnest weebs; Heart filled to brim the power of friendship and anime, lacking any and all shame. Most people who've seen the film have laughed, many have cried, a few dubbed it incomprehensible, and one called it absolute dreck!
This is the first time the film will be screened to the public, will it bring you down memory lane or drive you to madness? In anime convention tradition, the documentary screening will be paired with a couple of classic anime con panels so get there early!: Anime Burger Time by Evan Minto (Azuki.co, Ani-Gamers) The Great Gundam Gebate, featuring a panel of Newtype Level Gundam Nerds. We encourage old cosplay and kigurumi's to this totally free event!
Hope you join us Sunday, March 16th from 2PM to 5PM!

events.name: GLHF! VGM and Digital Fusion Party
events.description:
A wild night of video game music, math rock, digital fusion and beyond. Join four new voices on the cutting edge of a new scene in Brooklyn.
GLHF - GLHF (Good Luck Have Fun) is a raucous party band specializing in fast-paced and layered synth-rock, jazz fusion, and hyperpop remixes of video game music, often mashed with music from anime and pop/internet culture. Led by Joe Etzine and featuring VGM giants including Dom Palombi, Khrys Williams, and others who have frequented the mainstages of Magfest and PAX East, GLHF is currently playing shows across the East Coast.
Visit
https://linktr.ee/jetzine
for clips and social media.
Maxo - Max Coburn, often under the name ‚ÄòMaxo‚Äô is a musician and sound designer from Brooklyn, New York who specializes in digitally produced music, channelling a wide array of style and influence from Jazz, to Digital Fusion, to various types of dance music and beyond.
Visit
http://maxo.audio
Redddaz - is the spirit of Brooklyn in one man. This melting pot of American, Afro-Caribbean, and Afro-Latino cultures is not only the foundation of his music, but also his plane ticket to the rest of the world. Understanding that music ties us all together, this songwriter and producer seeks to bring a little piece of Brooklyn on his travels around the globe.
Visit
http://www.redddaz.com
Teal Jay - Fronted by Tyler Lee Jones, Teal Jay is a Brooklyn-based math rock project centered around their overhand guitar technique. They're influenced by artists in the NY/NJ indie emo/math punk and adjacent scenes (Invalids, Use Big Words, The Best of the Worst) as well as early 2000's J-rock/J-punk (STANE PUNKS, Sambomaster, AKFG).
Visit
linktr.ee/tylerleejones

Neurodivergence in Academia
events.description: <p>This session in partnership with University Life is part of Integrity Week 2025. Those with ADHD, autism, dyslexia, or other neurodivergent experiences often have to conform to a society that was inherently built to disadvantage the way they exist in the world. In this presentation we will begin scratching the surface on the challenges neurodivergent individuals face within a capitalist system, including workplace accommodations, societal biases, and economic disparities. We will discuss the potential benefits of neurodiversity in fostering innovation and creativity, while also shedding light on the urgency of dismantling ableist structures to create inclusive and equitable institutions that value diverse cognitive perspectives. We will end with some tips and suggestions on how to support our neurodivergent students and peers.</p>

events.name: Exploring Credit
events.description:
<p>Credit impacts many aspects of everyday life in the US. Your ability to access financial products and services, housing, and even cell phone or internet service can be influenced by your credit score. In spite of that fact, or perhaps because of it, understanding the credit system can feel confusing and overwhelming. What factors determine your credit score? How can you improve your credit score, and what rights do you have to dispute your credit report?</p>
<p>In this webinar a TrustPlus financial coach will answer these questions and provide tips for managing your credit score as part of an overall personal financial plan.</p>

<p>This is a monthly workshop for&nbsp;caregivers and patients across the Department of Neurology&nbsp;to understand how to access important &ldquo;concrete&rdquo; services that you or your loved ones may need throughout their treatment journey. We will discuss important topics such as transportation, disability, enrolling in Medicaid, advance care planning, as well as managing the emotional burden of caregiving.&nbsp;</p>

Registration is not required.&nbsp;</p>

Virtual Cooking Demo: Budget Friendly Meal Prep
events.description:
<p>Does it ever feel like eating healthy can be so expensive? If so, you&rsquo;re not alone! Utilizing pantry staples, including canned foods, is an effective and delicious way to eat healthy without breaking the bank. Join us for a live virtual food demo, where Registered Dietitian, Molly Chanzis, will demonstrate how to make the viral dense bean salad for under $5 per serving, while sharing other budget friendly tips and tricks along the way.</p>
<p><strong>Presenter:</strong>&nbsp;Molly Chanzis, MS, RD, CDN, CDCES is a Registered Dietitian who has been practicing for more than 10 years. Molly is passionate about making nutrition attainable to all and believes in sustainable lifestyle changes instead of quick fixes. She likes to focus on what foods and habits to add to your life, instead of taking things away. You can find Molly on social media <strong>@sayyestothefreshh</strong> where she shares healthy recipes, nutrition tips, and weekly meal plan ideas. She also sees patients through the virtual platform Culina Health.</p>

events.description: <p>The remarkable Stile Antico marks its twentieth season by honoring the 500th anniversary of one of the greatest masters of Renaissance polyphony, Giovanni Pierluigi da Palestrina, whose career was inextricably intertwined with the Papacy and the great churches of Rome for which he composed. The program includes some of the composer&rsquo;s most beloved and timeless motets, gems by other leading composers active in Rome at that time, and a new work by British composer Cheryl Frances-Hoad, written especially for this occasion.</p>

events.name: PhD in Urban Planning Lecture: Libby Porter (RMIT)
events.description:
<p>The 2025 PhD in Urban Planning Lecture, &ldquo;The Trouble With Land and Housing Justice: Views From a Settler Colony&rdquo; will be delivered by&nbsp;<strong>Libby Porter</strong>&nbsp;(RMIT), with a response by&nbsp;<strong>Tom Slater</strong>&nbsp;(GSAPP).</p>
<p>Planning for land and housing in settler colonial cities is structurally ruined. Devised as a regime to spatialise settler-colonialism, urban land-use planning continues to enable dispossession, expulsion and extraction at scales from the mundane to the spectacular. Drawing inspiration from the Indigenous concept of Country in so-called Australia and the fact of Indigenous sovereignty-never-ceded, the lecture will examine contemporary housing and land politics and struggles, and trouble the view of land, planning, housing and justice from a site of structural ruin.</p>

events.name: Composer Portraits: Jessie Montgomery
events.description: <p>The music of composer Jessie Montgomery is &ldquo;turbulent, wildly colorful, and exploding with life&rdquo;<em>&nbsp;(The Washington Post),</em>&nbsp;and is performed regularly by leading orchestras and ensembles around the globe. Winner of the 2024 Grammy Award for Best Classical Composition and Musical America&rsquo;s 2023 Composer of the Year, the Juilliard-trained violinist is immersed in a diverse range of projects, including The Everything Band&mdash;a collective of artists of varying styles creating music by experimentation, improvisation, and open-ended form. Montgomery performs alongside the ensemble for this Portrait, featuring a newly commissioned work and the hauntingly beautiful&nbsp;<em>Source Code&nbsp;</em>for string quartet.</p>

events.name: Hirshon Artist in Residence: Exploring Cinema Through the Visionary Lens of Ernest Dickerson
events.description: Each year, the School of Media Studies invites a distinguished film and media artist as the Hirshon Artist-In-Residence to lead master classes and screenings. For Spring 2025, under the theme "Writing with The Camera," we welcome renowned filmmaker and cinematographer Ernest Dickerson.Known for his work on Do the Right Thing, Malcolm X, and Juice, Dickerson‚Äôs visionary storytelling blends bold narratives with striking visuals. As both a director and cinematographer, he has shaped the look of iconic films and TV series like The Wire and Dexter.Exploring the power of visual storytelling, Dickerson‚Äôs residency will highlight how cinematography and direction function as forms of authorship. With his ability to balance bold narratives with striking visuals, he has left an indelible mark on both film and television.Through master classes and a public screening moderated by Vladan Nikolic, Dickerson will share insights into his craft and legacy.A reception will follow the discussion.

events.name: ONLINE | Careers in US Diplomacy and Foreign Service
events.description: The Graduate Program in International Affairs at The New School invites you to an Online Session on¬†Careers in US Diplomacy and Foreign Service with alum Kenya James.Kenya Jordana James is a Foreign Service Officer who joined the U.S. Department of State in 2015. Before joining the Department, Kenya worked as a press assistant with the U.S. Senate Democratic Policy and Communication Center. In 2013, she was awarded the Charles B. Rangel Fellowship, which supports outstanding individuals pursuing careers in the Foreign Service. Kenya began her diplomatic career as a Consular Officer at the U.S. Consulate in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam. She later served as the Assistant Public Affairs Officer at the U.S. Embassy in Conakry, Guinea, where she specialized in cultural outreach and strengthening U.S.-Guinea exchanges through Embassy programming and initiatives.¬† From 2022 to 2023, Kenya served as a Political Officer at the U.S. Embassy in Bangkok, working on the Myanmar pro-democracy movement as part of the Diplomatic Support Unit. In 2023, she moved to Niamey, Niger, to serve as the Public Affairs Officer (PAO), leading U.S. public diplomacy efforts. Kenya has been recognized as an emerging leader in foreign policy. In 2021, she was selected as one of the Aspen Strategy Group‚Äôs Rising Leaders. In 2023, she was selected as a Stephen M. Kellen Term Member by the Council on Foreign Relations. She holds a Bachelor‚Äôs degree in Political Science from Howard University and a Master‚Äôs in International Affairs from The New School.¬†Kenya will be in conversation with Sean Jacobs, Director, and Phil Akre, Associate Director, of GPIA.¬†

events.name: Racial Wellness
events.description: In the words of the legendary Black Southern organizer Fannie Lou Hamer, so many of us today are ‚Äúsick and tired of being sick and tired.‚ÄùThis sentiment rings especially true now as we navigate the expanding intersections of anti-Blackness and capitalism, systems that work tirelessly to relegate Black people and other marginalized communities to a permanent second-class status.Join us as we come together to discuss strategies, share tools, and find ways to collectively survive this moment.Free Food!¬†¬†Eugene Lang Building,¬†Room¬†500Wollman Hall¬†65 w 11th StreetNearby Trains: 6av, L train;1-3 trains, 14th St.Accessibility: Wheelchair Accessible.¬†

The event will also feature an interactive audience Q&A, providing a deeper exploration of his approach to directing and storytelling.This master class is a part of the Dorothy Hirshon Artist-in-Residence program. events.name: Inventing the Modern: Untold Stories of the Women Who Shaped The Museum of Modern Art
events.description: Join editors Ann Temkin and Romy Silver-Kohn on Wednesday, February 26th at 6:00pm for a discussion of their book, Inventing the Modern: Untold Stories of the Women Who Shaped The Museum of Modern Art.Inventing the Modern is a revelatory account of the Museum's early history told through newly commissioned profiles of fourteen women who, as founders, curators, patrons, and directors of various departments, made enduring contributions to MoMA during its first decades. Inventing the Modern tells the stories of trailblazing women, ranging from cofounder Abby Aldrich Rockefeller to longtime registrar Dorothy Dudley. Influential curators like Dorothy Miller shaped the course of American art and inventive leaders like MoMA's first director of publicity Sarah Newmeyer captured the public‚Äôs imagination. They created new models for how to envision, establish, and operate a museum in an era when the field of modern art was uncharted territory.

events.name: Africa's Charity Dependency
events.description: Professor Carlos Lopes will draw on his latest publication, The Self Deception Trap, which examines the complex relationship between Africa and Europe and how stigmatized narratives and substitute charity for economic transformation and development African leaders further these narratives in competing for external aid.Carlos Lopes is a leading African intellectual and thinker on global economic issues. He is an Honorary Professor at the Nelson Mandela School of Public Governance at the University of Cape Town and holds affiliate positions with Sciences Po in Paris, SOAS, Oxford University, and Cambridge University. He has served on several global policy commissions, advised governments, and held leadership positions at the UN, including as Executive Secretary of the Economic Commission for Africa (2012-2016).Chaired by:¬†Sakiko Fukuda-ParrDiscussant: Michael Cohen

events.name: Mannes Sounds: The Fantasy World of E.T.A. Hoffmann and His Influence
events.description: Curated by John Hargraves, Ph.DA tribute to E.T.A. Hoffmann: a German writer, philosopher, music critic and composer, who was a major influence on the Romantic movement in literature and music through fostering the artistic development of Schumann and Brahms and many other major composers and writers of the 19th and 20th centuries.Music by Hoffmann, Schumann, Brahms, Offenbach, Tchaikovsky/Pletnev and Mannes young composers. Dramatic readings from works by E.T.A. Hoffmann. Curated by John Hargraves, Ph.D.

events.name: The Homecoming - Documentary Screening
events.description: The Graduate Programs in International Affairs and the Foreign Press Association present: The Homecoming: Born in France but Searching for a Future in Africa, screening and discussion with BBC¬†Editorial Lead¬†Nathalie Jimenez.¬†¬†Africa Eye's Homecoming'¬†explores how marginalized communities in France are responding to rising nationalism, police violence, and social tensions - themes that resonate far beyond the country‚Äôs borders. The documentary highlights the¬†young French people of African descent, turning to the continent in search of, what they say, is a better life. It explores this "reverse migration", following their journeys to Senegal, the opposite their parents made decades earlier. All while capturing the challenges they face in building a new life away from what they know. The film sheds light on themes of belonging, identity, and the evolving relationship between Africa and its diaspora, offering a fresh perspective on migration and cross-cultural ties.A driving force behind The Homecoming,¬†Jimenez's¬†debut feature-length film draws inspiration from her own upbringing in Europe. The project reflects her commitment to uncovering untold narratives‚Äîtranscending traditional reporting to craft immersive, human-centered stories that resonate worldwide.¬†Conversation to include Sean Jacobs and¬†Kristen Saloomey, board member of the Foreign Press Association, which represents US based journalists working for foreign media outlets.

events.name: Philosophy Colloquium | Massimiliano Tomba, "Politics in the Age of Its Technical Reproducibility: Thinking with Walter Benjamin"
events.description: This event is open to current New School faculty and students only. You must have a New School email address to register.¬†Abstract: Walter Benjamin‚Äôs seminal essay,¬†The Work of Art in the Age of Its Technical Reproducibility, explores how new systems of work, machines, and techniques fundamentally reshape not only everyday sensory experiences, such as sight and hearing, but also space and time. Benjamin examines these transformations through the interplay of art and politics, grounding his analysis in the concept of ‚Äúrepresentation‚Äù and discussing its implications for both domains. He develops these reflections in relation to radio, photography, and film in the early twentieth¬†century. However, these reflections can be traced back to the invention of the printing press in the fifteenth century and forward to the present, which is dominated by new digital technologies. In each instance, the introduction of new technologies has provoked instability in the relationship between democracy and authority. This paper seeks to explore this tension further, highlighting the risks as well as the possibilities that such instability entails.¬†Bio:¬†Massimiliano Tomba serves as Chair and Professor in the History of Consciousness Department at the University of California, Santa Cruz. His research spans German philosophy, Critical Theory, Political Theory, Postcolonial Studies, and the Philosophy of History. Among his publications is¬†Insurgent Universality: An Alternative Legacy of Modernity¬†(Oxford University Press, 2019). His forthcoming book,¬†Revolution and Restoration: The Politics of Anachronism, is currently in publication with Fordham University Press.

events.name: ONLINE | Parsons Summer Intensive Studies 2025 | Pre-College¬†Webinar
events.description: Join us for another Parsons 2025 Summer Intensive Studies Pre-College webinar!Program Director Chris Musci, Assistant Director of Operations and Planning, Tomomi Tanikawa, Senior Manager of Enrollment Services, Jordan Artim, and Enrollment Coordinator, Casey Krosser will be available to answer your questions on¬†time structure, registration, activities, and the curriculum.Parsons Summer Intensives for Pre-College students offers students ages 16-18 an opportunity to study art and design with Parsons faculty at our Greenwich Village campus in NYC.We look forward to sharing¬†what you can expect¬†this coming summer¬†with live art and design studios.¬†Click the links below to browse dates, tuition, and more.New York Summer Intensive Studies (Ages 16‚Äì18)Session I¬†In-Person: June 9 - June 27 (3 credits, 3 weeks)Session II¬†In-Person: July 7 - July 25 (3 credits, 3 weeks)¬†¬†We look forward to meeting you online!

events.description: ¬†The Provost's Office continues to source opportunities to build our community's capacity to engage in meaningful dialogue, support peaceful protest, and de-escalate situations in the classroom and on campus. Skill-building and human connection are critical to creating a community of care.¬† Soul Focused, a grassroots leadership development organization,¬†will lead this comprehensive training for faculty and staff on¬†de-escalation¬†and conflict resolution. Role plays will address strategies for de-escalating¬†and maintaining¬†safe environments on campus.¬†This workshop is designed for New School faculty and staff. If you are a student interested in attending a training, please reach out to provost@newschool.edu.¬†

events.name: Malcolm 100X: A Radical Centenary
events.description: May 19, 2025 is the 100th anniversary of Malcolm X‚Äôs birth. This event celebrates his global legacy on Black nationalism, internationalism, and anti-colonial and anti-imperial movements. The celebration includes two academic panels, artistic installations, and community discussions.¬†Join us for two panel discussions on Feb. 28th. More details and times to follow.***‚ÄúWomen of Color and Malcolm X‚Äôs Enduring Legacy‚ÄùThis panel examines the profound impact that Black women had on Malcolm X's political thought as well as the enduring influence of his legacy on diverse women of color worldwide. Moderated by Dr. Mona Oraby, the first conversation features Mapping Malcolm editor Najha Zigbi-Johnson and Afro-Caribbean American Muslim artist Nsenga Knight, both of whom draw upon their creative practice and writing to explore how Black women shaped Malcolm‚Äôs evolving understanding of Black radicalism and internationalism. The second conversation highlights Dr. Maytha Alhassen and Dr. Denise Lim both of whom discuss how Malcolm X‚Äôs legacy continues to inspire Black-Arab and Black-Asian solidarities today.***"Malcolm X, Internationalist"The centenary of Malcolm X's birth offers a unique opportunity to explore his profound international impact beyond U.S. borders. This panel will analyze Malcolm‚Äôs advocacy for African Americans at the United Nations‚Äîlinking U.S. racism to internal colonialism, his relationship with the Islamic world and his trips to Africa, and his engagement with intellectuals and activists from outside the US not only influenced his perspectives on global liberation movements and socialism, but his relevance to contemporary political movements.

events.name: Philosophy Film Club Screening Series: Spring 2025
events.description: ‚ÄúWe all know that Art is not truth,‚Äù said the painter Pablo Picasso, ‚ÄúArt is a lie that makes us realize the truth, at least the truth that is given us to understand.‚Äù Because no human culture ever known has lived without art, we might wonder why such lies should be necessary. Perhaps it is, as the artist Percival Everett said of his own making, that Art informs our ‚Äúneed to make some sense of the world.‚Äù Each of the films in this semester‚Äôs series is a lie. Join us as we endeavor to decipher what truth of our shared world they help us make sense of.Everyone is welcome ‚Äî whether seasoned in philosophy or without any prior philosophical training ‚Äî with an interest in philosophy, film, and/or engaging in dialogues about what we experience. Each screening will begin and conclude with a discussion facilitated by a friend of the NSSR Philosophy Department. Snacks and beverages always provided.

events.name: Philosophy Film Club screening: ‚ÄòBorn in Flames‚Äô (dir. Lizzie Borden),¬†with facilitator Dr. Romy Opperman

Set in New York City, amidst a post-revolutionary America, this groundbreaking film that ‚Äúis absolutely one we should be watching right now‚Äù invites us to consider: What does true liberation require? Assistant Professor Romy Opperman (Philosophy, NSSR and Eugene Lang) will guide our discussion reflecting on this film‚Äôs depiction of solidarity and radical resistance. We invite you to join us. As always, snacks and beverages will be provided.For more information or to be added to the mailing list, email: veronica@newschool.edu

events.name: ONLINE | 10-Week Seminar: Political Economy of Energy Transition
events.description: This 10-week online course will cover the characteristics and challenges of energy transition. It will examine the political economy of transition, focusing on major changes that transfer to green and renewable energy will bring the global economy, politics, and geopolitics.¬†The energy transition that is driven by climate change is likely to bring fundamental transformation challenging the political and economic status quo across geographic areas. This course builds knowledge and provides critical tools for analyzing these changes and their effects on development, governance, and stability. To examine the effect of energy transition, we will cover various case studies demonstrating major common and specific trends in politics and economy caused by the decline of fossil fuels and the development of renewables.¬†Learning objectives:--Understand the basics of the political economy of energy resources and rentier states, economic approaches for achieving energy transition--Make assessments energy markets and their functions, classification of energy sources and energy transition--Analyze the global policy of energy transition, key aspects of Paris agreement, UN Climate Change conferences (COP28/29) and global methane pledge--Identify the economic, social, and political implications of energy transition--Critically analyze the influence of various kinds of resources (fossil fuels, renewables) on geopolitics, democracy building, stability, and sustainable development--Think strategically about energy transition and energy security

events.name: Lang Craft Talks featuring Shoshana von Blanckensee
events.description: The¬†Spring 2025¬†Lang Craft Talks¬†series¬†continues with Shoshana von Blanckensee.Shoshana von Blanckensee¬†lives in Berkeley, California, with her partner and kids. She is an Oncology Nurse by day, and a writer by any available moment. Her debut novel, Girls Girls Girls, will be released by Putnam in June 2025.Lang hosts a series of weekly dynamic and interactive lessons in the craft of writing. Each week features a different writer including Lang faculty, alumni and special guest writers.¬†¬†Visit the Lang Craft Talks¬†Hub for the full line-up of writers this semester!

events.name: At the Parsons Table: Paul Goldberger Series 3/3
events.description: In congruence with his spring 2024 course Paul Goldberger will be hosting At the Parsons Table, a series around design and social justice in New York City today, the third¬†guest in the series will be Wendy Evans Joseph.This series will be an insightful look into understanding what the future of Urban Life will look like, particularly in New York City. Goldberger and his guests¬†will investigate the state of architecture, design, and planning in New York today. Please register in the provided link to confirm your attendance. The event is open to the public and we welcome anyone who is interested in deepening their understanding of urban architecture design and life.¬†

events.name: Restoration and Resilience: Rebuilding Ukraine
events.description: Join us for a conversation with Victoria Caubet, an architect specializing in heritage conservation and sustainable construction, as she shares her expertise in rebuilding war-damaged infrastructure in Ukraine. Victoria, currently leading the reconstruction of a school through Neo-Eco Ukraine, will discuss the use of circular design and sustainable materials, community engagement, and addressing the traumatic impacts of war.Neo-Eco Ukraine is dedicated to transforming construction waste into resources for a greener future, showcasing innovative approaches to rebuilding communities while reducing environmental impact. The discussion will include insights into their work recycling materials from Ukraine‚Äôs war-damaged sites, promoting low-carbon solutions, and fostering local regeneration.This event will be moderated by Alison Mears, executive director and co-founder of the Healthy Materials Lab, who is also presenting¬†the work of a¬†senior architecture studio at Parsons exploring regenerative adaptive reuse in Kryvyi Rih, Ukraine.Free and open to the public. Don't miss this inspiring event on design, resilience, and sustainability!

events.name: ONLINE | 10-Week Seminar: Compound Violence against Women in War Zones: Case Studies of Syria and Sudan
events.description: This 10-week online seminar investigates the situation of the Syrian and Sudani women under authoritarian regimes, particularly during wartime. While some autocracies may promote women's rights to secure loyalty, Syria has a long-standing history of gender discrimination that intensified during the ongoing conflict.¬†Similarly, Sudan is currently experiencing unprecedented levels of conflict, with intense violence in regions like Khartoum, Darfur, and Kordofan. This ongoing crisis has significantly increased the dangers for women and girls, who face heightened risks of sexual violence, exploitation, and abuse.¬†This seminar seeks to shed light on the systematic repression of women activists and the difficulties they encounter. Topics will include methods of detention, the use of sexual assault as a weapon of humiliation, concepts of protection through the increase of child and minor marriages, escalation of crimes of honors,¬†challenges of the new life in displacement or exile, UN SC Resolution 1325 Women, Peace and Security: Issues and instruments.It advocates for a comprehensive strategy to empower women and ensure their meaningful involvement on all levels of governance, which is essential for achieving lasting peace in Syria and Sudan.

events.name: Roots Party with Edisa Weeks
events.description: Edisa Weeks/DELIRIOUS DANCES, The New School Scholar in Residence, invites you to join in the journey of making 1,865 roots out of paper and twine for her 3 RITES: LIBERTY installation.¬†Join us for a mash-up between a sewing bee and barbershop talk. Together we‚Äôll make roots, enjoy a meal prepared by a BIPOC-owned restaurant or caterer, and participate in a community discussion about what The New School community means to you.The entire New School community is welcome and people are free to come and go as they please.¬†Fun Fact: Each root is between 8 to 30 feet long and is designed to hang from the ceiling to the floor. As part of the 3 RITES: LIBERTY installation the roots will create a maze that the audience walks through, as if walking through the underbelly of American history, to eventually meet the Liberty character.

events.name: ONLINE | 10-Week Seminar: Human Beings and Society in the Information Hurricane: Threats of the Age of Hyperconnectivity
events.description: This 10-week online seminar offers a comprehensive examination of the multifaceted nature of information warfare, focusing on how political narratives, disinformation, and media influence shape both democratic processes and global conflicts. The course covers a wide range of themes, including the use of popular culture as a tool for political messaging, resilience and vulnerability factors in information disorders, and the long-term human cost of information warfare.Through case studies such as Russian information strategies across different geopolitical contexts, participants will analyze the tools, tactics, and platforms used to manipulate public opinion. The seminar will also explore how global and local narratives about justice, peace, and equality are influenced by these tactics, focusing on the ethical, social, and political consequences of the global struggle for truth in the media.

events.name: The 2025 Management and Social Justice Conference
events.description: Join us, in NYC, for three days of sharing, reflecting, learning, and co-creating! Come together with scholars and practitioners from around the globe for invigorating keynotes, interactive panel discussions, engaging workshops, thought provoking research presentations, and networking sessions. Expanding on discourse sparked at The New School Management and Social Justice Conversation Series¬†and the 2023 Management and Social Justice conference, this year, we are focused on the role of Technology in Management and Social Justice. Management and Social Justice Collective, created by Prof. Latha Poonamallee has brought together thousands of participants from 66 countries over the last five years. Organizing committee includes Dr. Simy Joy, independent scholar, Dr. Anita Howard (Case Western Reserve University), Dr. Joanne Scillitoe (California State University, Northridge), and Akhil, S.G. (Case Western).

events.name: Food and Social Justice Action Research Lab Seminar Series: ‚ÄúGreen grabbing‚Äù or land sharing? Power relations of landscape transformation in intensified agroecosystems
events.description: ‚ÄúGreening‚Äù industrial agriculture has been a stated goal of European policy for three decades, but agroecological schemes in place have so far had little effect on reducing its deleterious consequences on the environment. While the post-war transition to a highly mechanized and chemical-dependent large-scale agriculture was a systemic endeavor that mobilized all components of rural societies, agroecology is on the other end only timidly pushed, as a set of piecemeal instruments, by policymakers who do not wish to alter the free-market foundations of the food industry.In regions of historically intensive agriculture, where landscapes and ecosystems have been simplified to a minimum, the preservation and development of the few remaining ecosystem services have been seemingly ‚Äúoutsourced‚Äù from the farmers to a variety of public, private and non-profit actors‚Äîeach pursuing their own specific goal, from flood management to ecological compensation‚Äîand reconfiguring a landscape that had long lost its ecological amenities. But is the apparent divorce between agriculture and landscape production something to rejoice over? Who actually gets to shape rural productive landscapes and decide its uses? How much of a democratic process can‚Äîand should‚Äîlandscape production be? Based on the initial stages of a doctoral dissertation and through the example of a rural territory in Northern France, this presentation aims at opening a discussion on the power relations behind seemingly mundane but strategic landscapes.

events.name: How To Create Your Portfolio Website: A Workshop For Early-Career Journalists
events.description: Join veteran journalist and J+D professor Alvin Chang for a workshop on creating your own online portfolio, an essential tool to showcase your skills and experiences in journalism.¬†No prior coding or design knowledge is required!¬†Bring your laptop, or borrow one from the University Center. Beverages will be provided.**RSVP is required to attend.**

events.name: UGLINESS
events.description: Moshtari Hilal discusses her book¬†Ugliness¬†(New Vessel Press, 2025), translated from the German by Elisabeth Lauffer‚Äîdealing with attraction, repulsion and mounting pressures to conform to norms of appearance‚Äîwith¬†New York Times¬†columnist and Hofstra University literature professor Rhonda Garelick.How do power and beauty join forces to determine who is considered ugly? What role does that ugliness play in fomenting hatred? Moshtari Hilal, an Afghan-born author and artist who lives in Germany, has written a touching, intimate, and highly political book. Dense body hair, crooked teeth, and big noses: Hilal uses a broad cultural lens to question norms of appearance‚Äîostensibly her own, but in fact everyone‚Äôs. She writes about beauty salons in Kabul as a backdrop to the US invasion of Afghanistan, Darwin‚Äôs theory of evolution, Kim Kardashian, and a utopian place in the shadow of her nose. With a profound mix of essay, poetry, her own drawings, and cultural and social history of the body, Hilal explores notions of repulsion and attraction, taking the reader into the most personal of realms to put self-image to the test. Why are we afraid of ugliness?

events.name: ONLINE | 10-Week Seminar: Building Bridges: Topics in Arabic Literature in Translation
events.description: This free 10-week online course will delve into the profound role of translated Arabic literature in fostering a connection between Arab and Western cultures, aiming to transcend stereotypes and Orientalism. The seminar will examine the evolution of the translation movement for Arabic literary texts, probing the barriers that hinder the rightful recognition of Arabic literature in the broader literary canon. The curriculum is designed to assess how translated Arabic literature can contribute to enriching Arab cultural identity, countering historical stereotypes rooted in the Western consciousness.¬†Emphasizing the bridging of ages and cultures, the course explores seminal works like The Arabian Nights and Kalila Wa Dimnah while also delving into modern themes such as the intersection of Arabic literature and ecofeminism, and contemporary Arabic exile literature. Through engaging debates and readings, students are invited to cultivate a nuanced understanding of the challenges, controversies, and transformative potential inherent in the translation and reception of Arabic literary texts, ultimately fostering a meaningful connection between Arab and Western societies through the powerful medium of literature.

events.name: 2025 Employee Appreciation Day Brunch

Stop by the shop and then show off your school spirit by striking a pose in our photo booth!¬†We hope to see you there!Note: this event is for New School staff only.

events.name: Fred Hersch Masterclass: Accompanying for Vocalists
events.description: ‚Äúthe most arrestingly innovative pianist in jazz over the last decade‚Äù - Vanity Fair‚Äúa living legend‚Äù - The New YorkerFred Hersch Masterclass:¬†ÔªøAccompanying for VocalistsThis masterclass will focus on accompanying for vocalists.¬†¬†Don't miss this rare opportunity to learn from a true jazz master.¬†FREE WITH RSVP - SPACE IS LIMITED*Please note - the Jazz Performance Space has been renamed as Arnie Lawrence Hall and is located at The New School's College of Performing Arts at 55 West 13th ST. between 5/6th avenues, 5th FL.¬†FRED HERSCHA member of jazz‚Äôs piano pantheon, Fred Hersch has been an influential creative force over more than three decades as an improviser, composer, educator, bandleader, collaborator, and recording artist. He has been proclaimed ‚Äúthe most arrestingly innovative pianist in jazz over the last decade‚Äù by Vanity Fair and ‚Äúa living legend‚Äù by The New Yorker. A seventeen-time Grammy nominee, Hersch has garnered jazz‚Äôs most prestigious awards, including a Doris Duke Artist (2016), Jazz Pianist of the Year from the Jazz Journalists Association (2011, 2016, 2018), and the Jazz Magazine (France) International Artist of the Year (2021). The Fred Hersch Trio was voted the #1 Jazz Group in the 2019 DownBeat Critics Poll.

events.name: ONLINE | 10-Week Seminar: Natural and Manmade Hazards Under Changing Environments
events.description: This 10-week online seminar focuses on the multifaceted and complex impacts of natural and anthropogenic hazards on societies under changing environments. Natural impacts include droughts, flooding, landslides, wildfires, and anthropogenic impacts such as deforestation, armed conflict, environmental pollution and contamination, and climate change will be covered in the seminar.The course will familiarize students with key concepts, theories, and approaches in responding, studying, and assessing these hazards. This seminar is crucial in ensuring the safety and resilience of societies through effective mitigation strategies and emergency preparedness plans by the policymakers, stakeholders, and the wider community. This also helps to minimize the impacts of disasters on human lives, infrastructure, and the environment by ultimately creating more sustainable and resilient communities.¬†

events.name: Ruff Cuts 2 - Spring 2025
events.description: This event will be on campus. Registration is required.¬†We are extremely excited to announce the second RUFF CUTS of the Spring 2025 Semester, which will take place on Friday, March 7, 2025 from 6-9pm at Starr Foundation Hall - 63 Fifth Avenue.About RUFF CUTS¬†RUFF CUTS is the School of Media Studies' main screening event, where students and alumni screen their films and receive feedback from their colleagues and professors. The event attracts professors, alumni, festival programmers, industry professionals, and students across the university. It is an incredible opportunity to screen your work-in-progress films, receive feedback, and connect with other talented filmmakers from our community. We usually screen an average of 8 films on a first come, first served basis.¬†We are looking forward to seeing you!¬†The deadline to submit work to ruffcuts@newschool.edu is Sunday, March 2nd, 2025 (or before).¬†Follow our Instagram for the latest updates! @ruffcuts_tns

events.name: Handel's Alcina~presented by Mannes Opera
events.description: Witchcraft, transformation, love-sick fools, magic rings ‚Äì all taking place on an island. Alcina (1773) is one of Handel‚Äôs three operas based on Ludovico Ariosto‚Äôs epic work, Orlando Furioso (1516).The opera is a wild, messy story of love and deception ‚Äì a fairy tale with magic that accurately describes the pain and exaltation of falling in love. Mannes Opera is thrilled to work with director Sam Helfrich, and to welcome back esteemed Mannes alumnus Geoffrey McDonald as conductor with the Mannes Opera Orchestra.¬†March 7 & 8 at 7:00pm: Mannes Opera presents Handel‚Äôs AlcinaThe Gerald W. Lynch Theater at John Jay College, 524 West 59th Street (between 10th & 11th Avenues), New York, N.Y.MANNES OPERAUnder the leadership of Managing Artistic Director Emma Griffin, Mannes Opera is a dynamic training program for operatic artists, marked by a curiosity for new and a devotion to craft. The program utilizes opera as a medium for exploration, improvisation, and creation, providing students with extensive performance opportunities and practice. Recent notable productions include Grace McLean‚Äôs In the Green, Cavall‚Äôs La Calisto, Nico Muhly‚Äôs Dark Sisters, Die Zauberfl√∂te, Rachel J. Peter‚Äôs Mermaid in the Jar, and Kate Soper‚Äôs Here Be Sirens.¬† With our commitment to developing and supporting new opera, we have workshopped Missy Mazzoli and Royce Vavrek‚Äôs The Listeners, Gregory Spears and Tracy K. Smith‚Äôs The Righteous (in collaboration with Santa Fe Opera), and David T. Little‚Äôs Agamemnon (in collaboration with Theatre for a New Audience). Our mission is to empower students to become versatile and self-assured professional artists, equipped with the skills and agency to navigate the ever-evolving landscape of the performing arts. Mannes Opera is committed to fostering artistic excellence and innovation, guided by the rich traditions of the past and a bold vision for the future.¬†Mannes Opera‚Äôs 2024/25 Season opens with a jewel box production of Don Giovanni created by Griffin and Mannes faculty member Cris Frisco, presented in a crisp 100 minutes, on October 18 and 19. The Opera in Concert double bill on November 8 and 9 features works by Mannes faculty members and prolific composers, David T. Little (Vinkensport, or the Finch Opera, New York City premiere) and Kamala Sankaram (The Infinite Energy of Ada Lovelace), directed by New School Drama alum Alison Pogolrec. On March 7 and 8, Mannes Opera presents Handel‚Äôs Alcina at the Gerald W. Lynch Theater, directed by Sam Helfrich and conducted by Mannes alumnus Geoffrey McDonald. events.name: AI for Africa: Learning from the Bangladeshi experience
events.description: In contemporary society, the intersection of artificial intelligence (AI) and governance presents unparalleled opportunities for transformative development, particularly through the lens of South-South cooperation. Emerging economies, such as Bangladesh, exemplify how collaborative frameworks and resource-sharing between developing nations can accelerate AI adoption in governance. The application of AI technology in administrative processes, particularly in bridging institutional voids and leveraging complementary asset portfolios, promises to revolutionize the efficiency and efficacy of governance complementary asset portfolios, promises to revolutionize the efficiency and efficacy of governance systems. This panel explores the potential of AI to drive sustainable development and enhance public service delivery by addressing the gaps within governance structures often caused by institutional voids‚Äîscenarios where formal institutions are weak or absent. This exploration highlights Bangladesh and other developing nations that are leveraging South-South cooperation to share AI-driven solutions and strategies for overcoming governance challenges. By integrating AI into governance, these countries can address institutional voids more effectively, building adaptive, responsive systems even in regions with fragile institutions.¬†

events.name: Kenneth Koch at 100: A Celebration
events.description: ¬†The Kenneth Koch Literary Estate and the New School invite you to a celebration of the life and work of Kenneth Koch, poet, teacher, playwright, fiction writer, and collaborator with artists. Koch, who taught at The New School from 1958 to 1966, is a major poet of New York ‚Äì alongside his friends John Ashbery, Frank O‚ÄôHara and James Schuyler ‚Äì and a teacher who inspired generations of young writers. Participants include film director Jim Jarmusch, critic Lucy Sante, artists Jim Dine and Alex Katz, legendary editor of Paris Review Maxine Groffsky, essayist Phillip Lopate, and poets Ron Padgett, Charles North, Tony Towle, John Keene, and Jeffrey Harrison. Poet and editor Jordan Davis will host the event, with a general introduction by Robert Polito of The New School.During his lifetime, Koch published more than a dozen collections of poems including Thank You, The Pleasures of Peace, The Art of Love, Days and Nights, One Train, and New Addresses. Among his posthumous volumes are Collected Poems, On the Edge: Collected Long Poems, The Banquet: Collected Plays and The Collected Fiction of Kenneth Koch. He is also the author of two trailblazing books on teaching writing to children, Wishes, Lies and Dreams and Rose, Where Did You Get That Red?¬†Koch received the Library of Congress‚Äô Rebekah Johnson Bobbitt National Prize for Poetry and the Bollingen Prize for Poetry. He was a member of the American Academy of Arts and Letters, received Fulbright and Guggenheim fellowships, and was named Chevalier dans l'Ordre des Arts et des Lettres by the French government. Koch‚Äôs teaching career in New York, beginning with three years at Brooklyn College and nine years at the New School, concluded at Columbia, where he taught from 1959 until 2002.

events.name: Designing the Future: Leveraging Technology for 1.5¬∞C Lifestyles: Raz Godelink
events.description: This workshop addresses the urgent need for transformative shifts in lifestyles, particularly in the Global North, to limit global warming to 1.5¬∞C. It explores how companies can harness technology-driven innovation and sustainable design to facilitate this transition. Drawing on Raz Godelnik‚Äôs Business-Driven 1.5¬∞C Lifestyles Framework (BD1.5LF), participants will work on industry-specific scenarios to tackle real-world challenges, with a focus on the Innovation and Sustainable Design opportunity area. The session will emphasize the importance of balancing radical thinking with innovation and demonstrate how businesses can redesign their approach to climate action. By harnessing technological innovation through a designerly approach, companies can support the shift to 1.5¬∞C lifestyles, which, in turn, will advance their efforts to meet climate targets.

events.name: Carceral Political Economy in the Era of Late Mass Incarceration
events.description: What is the political economy of ‚Äúlate‚Äù mass incarceration? How has the globally unparalleled US system of mass imprisonment remained impervious to two decades of critique and a decade of anti-carceral mass-mobilization? The harms of mass incarceration are well documented, and its failure to foster safety in our communities is, in the academy at least, uncontroversial. However, the current levels of government spending are themselves politically uncontroversial, whilst political elites are again timorous about reform as the MAGA movement reinvigorates the debased ‚Äòtough vs. soft‚Äô on crime discourse.¬†This conference seeks to turn the lens of political economy on this apparent impasse, in the hope that attention to the distribution and contestation of power and resources can help us to understand the resilience of these institutions, and to move past modest declines in aggregate incarceration rates and into an actual post-mass-incarceration future.This conference is¬†open to anyone¬†invested in understanding or achieving a decarceral transition (academics, organizers, everyone).--------------------------------------------------------------------------------¬†Call For Papers from Graduate Students:We will include exciting graduate student work from across disciplines that addresses the conference's core questions. The work can be complete or in progress. Submit a brief abstract to¬†Dion Nania¬†(nanid359@newschool.edu) and¬†Eric Seligman (selig056@umn.edu) by January 31, 2025. Unfortunately, we do not have funds available to assist with travel, but we will provide a couple meals and some beverages at the event.¬†Non-exhaustive list of possible topics:-What is the relationship between the carceral state, broadly defined, and labor markets?-What is the role of prison work in the carceral political economy?-What can we learn from the application of a racial capitalism lens?-What defines the contemporary post-COVID period within neoliberal capitalism, and what is the nature of the associations between these economic trends and penal trends?-How can a comparative lens help bring into view what is truly unique about the disposition and staying power of carceral solutions in the U.S.?-What is the political economy of the proliferation of 'cop cities'?-How does analysis of carceral political economy inform the praxis of contemporary anti-carceral social movements?Please reach out to the organizers with any questions: Dion Nania (nanid359@newschool.edu) and Eric Seligman (selig056@umn.edu).¬†Funded in part by the NSSR Dean's Conference Fund

events.name: As for Protocols Book Launch
events.description: Explicitly‚Äîor not‚Äîprotocols determine much of what we do. Far exceeding traditional notions of ‚Äúgood manners,‚Äù protocols are systems of language that regulate how we relate to each other, to our cultural, social, and political environments, and to the technologies that create them. The first publication to look at protocols across a wide range of disciplines, As for Protocols¬†features essays, artworks, conversations, and scores by twenty-four international contributors who speak to protocols as practice‚Äîneither conventional mannerisms nor abstract concepts, but material processes, relational affinities, shared responsibilities, and mutual care. What emerges from the book‚Äôs pages are tools for empowerment, ways in which protocols can be rebooted, reengineered, embodied, appropriated, and used to our own ends.The As for Protocols launch brings together the book‚Äôs editors‚ÄîRe‚Äôal Christian, Carin Kuoni, and Eriola Pira‚Äîwith contributors: artist Salome Asega, scholar Shannon Mattern, performer Silas Riener, and artist Robert Sember of the sound art collective Ultra-red. Using the book as a prompt, performances, readings, and conversations with the contributors speak to protocols through their technological, political, and social dimensions.¬†Order As for Protocols here‚Äîthe open access ebook¬†is now available online.As for Protocols is co-published by the Vera List Center for Art and Politics and Amherst College Press, with an opening score by Raven Chacon and contributions by Salome Asega, Carolina Caycedo with Lupita Lim√≥n Corrales, Jesse Chun, Asia Dorsey, Taraneh Fazeli and Cannach MacBride, Pablo Helguera, Emmanuel Iduma, Mary Maggic, Shannon Mattern, V. Mitch McEwen with Nadir Jeevanjee, Rashaun Mitchell with Silas Riener, Romy Opperman, Rasheedah Phillips, Leanne Betasamosake Simpson with Maria Hupfield, Ultra-red with Robert Sember, and Underground Resistance.

events.name: Memorial in Honor of Jerome Kohn
events.description: This memorial is to honor the life and legacy of philosopher Jerome Kohn (1931-2024), who taught at The New School for Social Research and played a leading role in building tahe Liberal Studies MA Program, which he directed from 1980 to 1985.¬†In addition to being a dedicated teacher and writer, as well as a cherished interlocutor, Jerome Kohn‚Äôs influence on the discipline was felt through his monumental contributions to the reception of Hanah Arendt‚Äôs thought. As a long-time executor and trustee of Arendt‚Äôs literary estate, he edited, published, and wrote introductions to numerous books, essays, and other writings that have played an essential role in disseminating her work and shaping her legacy over the past 30 years.¬†Please join us in honoring, remembering and celebrating Jerome Kohn, his keen insight, kindness, dedication and commitment, and his enduring contributions both to The New School community and to the discipline at large.¬†¬†¬†*********************************************************************Jerome (Jerry) Kohn was a philosopher, a preeminent scholar and confidante of Hannah Arendt, and a crucial member of the NSSR‚Äôs liberal studies program.¬†Kohn completed his undergraduate degree in literature at Harvard University and proceeded to graduate study in philosophy at Columbia University. He met Hannah Arendt in the late 1960s and continued his studies with her at The New School for Social Research, while also working as her teaching and research assistant. When Arendt died in December 1975, Kohn spoke at her funeral on behalf of Arendt‚Äôs students. Following¬†Arendt's death, Kohn worked with the American writer Mary McCarthy and German literary scholar Lotte K√∂hler, then trustees of Arendt‚Äôs literary estate, on transferring her papers and library to the archives of the Library of Congress and of Bard College. McCarthy‚Äôs posthumous edition of Arendt‚Äôs¬†The Life of the Mind¬†(1978) is based on years of assistance and collaboration with Kohn.¬† He was director of the Master of Arts in Liberal Studies program at The New School from 1980 to 1985, which he was instrumental in creating, and was the founding director of the Hannah Arendt Center at the New School for Social Research in New York. In 2001, he became trustee of the Hannah Arendt Bluecher Literary Trust. In addition to directing the Center at the New School, Kohn facilitated the formation of Arendt Centers at the University of Oldenburg (Germany) and at Bard College, where he received an honorary degree in 2022. In 2019, he¬†was awarded the ‚ÄúHannah Arendt Prize for Political Thought‚Äù (Bremen/Germany). Kohn‚Äôs support was essential in the establishment of the new¬†Critical Edition of the Complete Works of Hannah Arendt¬†(Wallstein Verlag, 2018-present). He maintained correspondence with a great network of scholars, writers, archivists, and artists throughout the world and was an indispensable resource for information about Arendt‚Äôs life and work. He was also a trusted friend and advisor, and a peerless raconteur.

events.name: Design with the Ocean: Aquatic Plants and Healthy Materials
events.description: When our oceans are healthy our world is healthy. Oceans¬†play a critical role in¬†regulating our climate and weather patterns, and provide a wide range of food and medicinal ingredients, and countless species. However, fossil fuels are threatening the health of oceans. Carbon emissions increase ocean temperatures and acid levels, and pollutants such as microplastics threaten marine biodiversity as well as human health and safety.¬†Oceans also offer a variety of rapidly renewable plant resources that can support a petroleum-free future for design.¬†Plants native to water, such as eelgrass, algae and seaweed, represent an exciting frontier in material science. Innovators and manufacturers are discovering their potential to replace harmful materials with new, healthy alternatives.¬†This virtual event brings together leaders at the forefront of manufacturing biobased materials using native sea plants as ingredients to create products with a multitude of health and environmental benefits.¬†Join leading manufacturers in conversation with a marine biologist who will provide a context for climate solutions from the worlds ocean.RSVP Today!

Palladino‚Äôs research centers on the political economy of corporations and finance.Palladino is also the author of a book on the political economy of corporations: Good Company: Economic Policy After Shareholder Primacy, published by the University of Chicago Press.During her presentation, she will discuss current issues in the political economy of corporations, drawing from her book, plus more recent work on unregulated financial markets. External guests, please register¬†here so that security at our building has your name; otherwise you¬†may be denied entry.

events.name: Book Talk | Borders and Belonging: Toward a Fair Immigration Policy
events.description: A uniquely broad and fair-minded guide to making immigration policy ethical. Immigration is now a polarizing issue across most advanced democracies. But too much that is written about immigration fails to appreciate the complex responses to the phenomenon. Too many observers assume imaginary consensus, avoid basic questions, or disregard the larger context for human migration. In Borders and Belonging, Hiroshi Motomura offers a complex and fair-minded account of immigration, its root causes, and the varying responses to it. Taking stock of the issue's complexity, while giving credence to the opinions of immigration critics, he tackles a series of important questions that, when answered, will move us closer to a more realistic and sustainable immigration policy.

events.description: ¬†Throughout history, a limited group of individuals have contributed significantly to establishing an architectural lighting design community in global, regional, and local contexts. These pioneers have paved the way for new groups of future designers to integrate light's creative, technical, social, emotional, and physiological performance into architectural projects. Presenters from the IES New York City History Committee will share details of the conditions that led Richard Kelly to establish his architectural lighting design practice, the first in the USA and globally.The program will introduce the Pioneers of Architectural Lighting research initiative aimed at documenting contributions of individuals throughout the world by sharing updates from nations including Brazil, China, Colombia, Egypt, France, Greece, India, Indonesia, Korea, Lebanon, Pakistan, Philippines, Russia, Taiwan, Turkey, Ukraine, United Arab Emirates, and the USA. Attendees will learn about opportunities to access information about our shared history and participate in the ongoing process of telling the story of our profession.¬†
